content: This comprehensive guide covers diagnostic procedures for common radiator problems including airlocks, valve failures, and blockages. It provides systematic troubleshooting approaches for heating engineers.
### How Radiators Work in Central Heating Systems
- Hot water from the boiler flows into radiators
- Heat transfers from the water to the radiator body
- Radiator releases heat into the room
- Cooled water returns to the boiler
- **Radiator Body**: Metal casing that transfers heat
- **Thermostatic Radiator Valve (TRV)**: Controls water flow based on room temperature
- **Lockshield Valve**: Balances water flow across the system (opposite end to TRV)
## PART 2: COMMON RADIATOR FAULTS AND DIAGNOSIS
- Top of radiator cold, bottom warm
- Check if problem affects a single radiator or multiple units
- Listen for gurgling sounds when system is running
- Observe heating pattern (cold spots vs. completely cold)
- Insert radiator key and turn slowly counterclockwise
- If air hisses out, confirms airlock is present
- If only water appears immediately, airlock may be elsewhere
- Check multiple radiators, starting with highest point in system
- If multiple radiators contain air, likely a system-wide issue
- If only one radiator consistently develops airlocks, pipe routing or valve issue may be the cause
- Incorrect pipe routing creating air traps
- Radiator stays cold despite TRV being on high setting
- Radiator stays hot despite TRV being on low setting
- Ensure TRV isn't set to frost protection (usually '*' or '0')
- Turn to maximum setting and wait 30 minutes
- Remove TRV head (usually unscrews or unclips)
- Locate pin in center of valve
- Pin should move smoothly with spring resistance
- If stuck, tap gently with small hammer
- If pin moves but radiator remains cold, internal valve problem likely
- Pin should extend as wax expands
- No movement indicates failed thermostatic element
- System imbalance (some radiators too hot, others too cold)
- Turn valve stem clockwise to close
- Feel resistance at fully closed position
- Check for water around valve body and spindle
- Inspect valve packing gland for deterioration
- Look for mineral deposits indicating slow leaks
- Bleed radiator to confirm no water flow
- If water continues flowing when valve is closed, valve seat is damaged
- Bottom of radiator cold while top is hot
- Cold spots in middle of radiator
- Radiator takes much longer to heat than others
- Radiator remains cold despite valves being open
- Feel radiator surface to map cold areas
- Bottom cold, top hot: Major sludge buildup
- Completely cold: Full blockage or valve issue
- Open bleed valve and observe flow rate
- Slow or discolored flow indicates blockage
- Drain small amount of water from radiator into clear container
- Check for discoloration, particles, or sludge
- Black water indicates magnetite (iron oxide) buildup
- Brown water indicates general system corrosion
- Age of system (older systems more susceptible)
- Corrosion from mixed metals in system
- Check if problems correlate with distance from boiler
- If one radiator affected: Likely localized issue
- If all radiators affected: Likely system-wide issue
- If pattern follows pipe route: Possible partial blockage
- If upper floors affected differently than lower: Possible pump or pressure issue
1. Attach pressure gauge to radiator drain valve
2. Compare pressure reading to system specification
4. Excessive pressure may indicate expansion vessel issues
- Thermal imaging camera or infrared thermometer
1. Allow system to run for at least 30 minutes
2. Scan radiator surface with thermal imaging device
3. Identify cold spots that aren't visible by touch
1. Collect water sample from radiator drain valve
2. Allow to settle in clear container
3. Run magnet along outside of container
4. Magnetite (black sludge) will be attracted to magnet
5. Severity indicates level of system corrosion
2. Insert radiator key into bleed valve
5. Check system pressure and top up if necessary
1. Check for and fix any leaks in system
2. Consider automatic air vents at high points
4. In severe cases, power flush system
5. Use PTFE tape on threads when reinstalling
1. Add system cleaner to heating system
2. Run system at high temperature for 2-4 hours
- Flush with garden hose in reverse direction
3. Install magnetic filter to prevent recurrence
1. Bleed all radiators at start of heating season
3. Visually inspect all valves for leaks
4. Run system and check all radiators heat properly
4. Inspect all radiator valves for function
1. Use appropriate inhibitor for system type
2. Consider biocide if bacterial growth suspected
1. Install magnetic filter on return to boiler
4. Install automatic air vents at high points
| Temperature Pattern | Most Likely Cause | Secondary Causes |
| Top cold, bottom hot | Trapped air | Partially closed valve |
| Bottom cold, top hot | Sludge buildup | Pipework design issue |
| Middle cold spot | Partial blockage | Manufacturing defect |
| Cold near TRV | Faulty TRV | Blocked valve |
| Cold near lockshield | Closed/faulty lockshield | Pipe blockage |
| Completely cold | Closed valves | Major blockage, airlock |
| Lukewarm throughout | System imbalance | Undersized boiler/pump |
| Stuck pin | Scale/debris buildup | Clean pin, replace if necessary |
| No resistance in head | Failed wax element | Replace TRV head |
| Head loose | Worn connection | Replace head or entire valve |
| Leaking from stem | Worn packing gland | Tighten gland nut or replace valve |
| Water hammer when closing | Rapid valve closure | Install flow restrictor |
| Head does not click | Broken internal mechanism | Replace TRV head |
- Be aware water may be very hot
- Drain slowly to prevent vacuum locks
- Store chemicals away from children and pets
- Avoid mixing different brands of chemicals
- Document chemicals used for future reference
- Isolate and drain affected radiator only
- Use correct size spanners to avoid damage
- Have spare PTFE tape and olives ready
- Consider union connections to simplify future work
